Main-title: Receiving a letter of demand
Description: Understanding what you can do when you receive a letter of demand / cease and desist.
Additional-disclaimer: Before responding to a letter of demand, you may want to show the letter and explain the situation to a qualified IP legal professional  who can explain your  who can explain your position and outline possible options.

Main-title: Choose not to respond immediately
Description: When to delay responding to groundless IP infringement claims and how to gather evidence for future defence.

Main-title: Pause use of contested IP until resolution
Description: Evaluate the accuser’s demands and consider stopping use of the contested IP to avoid escalation.
Additional-disclaimer: Please note: Ceasing use of the contested IP alone may not be sufficient to prevent further escalation. It can also have negative consequences on your ability to respond to allegations of infringement or be seen as an admission of liability. Please consider carefully if you want to undertake this action and are fully aware of the risks involved. An IP lawyer or IP attorney can help you assess the strength of the allegations made against you and whether ceasing use of the contested IP is in your best interests.

Main-title: Obtain legal advice on an accusation of infringment
Description: Seek expert advice on how to respond to allegations of IP infringement

Main-title: Register your trade mark
Description: Apply to IP Australia for a registered trade mark to secure exclusive rights to your brand  to reinforce your defence.
Resolution-rate: Approximately 75% of trade mark applications achieve registration

Main-title: Respond to an opposition filed against your trade mark
Description: How to respond when someone has opposed your trade mark application

Main-title: Respond to an opposition filed against your patent
Description: How to respond when someone has opposed your patent application
Resolution-rate: IP Australia’s published 54 decisions in 2024 and 66 decisions in 2023.

Main-title: Challenge a granted patent
Description: Challenge the validity of a patent that you are accused of infringing.
Resolution-rate: <1% of patents are subject to re-examination

Main-title: Report a scam, fraud or risk to public interest
Description: Notify authorities about scams, counterfeits, or fraudulent activities that pose a risk to public safety or trust.

Main-title: De-escalate and resolve disputes via conversation
Description: Engage in an informal conversation to resolve IP disputes

Main-title: Respond to an unjustified threat
Description: Use the court to respond to a legally unjustified demand or threat
Resolution-rate: Court decisions are binding although appeal is possible
Additional-disclaimer: It is always prudent to seek legal advice before deciding whether to start legal action. There are often options other than court for responding to an unjustified threat — like writing back to the other party to clarify your position — before you decide whether to start legal action against them. An IP lawyer or IP attorney can help you decide on the best way to respond.

Main-title: Reach an agreement with the accusing party
Description: Negotiate a mutually acceptable commercial or financial resolution.
Resolution-rate: Over 90% of commercial disputes settle outside court or arbitration

Main-title: Assert your rights, as a response to an accusation
Description: If you believe that you are genuinely in the right to retain your IP, gather evidence and defend your right to use it.

Main-title: Considerations when responding to international accusations
Description: Find the right assistance for responding to accusations of IP infringement happening outside of Australia.

Main-title: Request IP Australia confirms a registered design is valid
Description: Request IP Australia examines and certifies a registered design to secure full protection
Additional-disclaimer: You can only take formal action to protect your design right — like sending a letter of demand (or cease-and-desist letter) — after your design is certified. A threat to start infringement or similar proceedings against another person in respect of a design will be an unjustified threat if the design has not been certified. A person who receives such a threat can start legal action against the person making the threat. For more information, please see Unjustified Threats.

Main-title: Oppose an IP infringement notice from an online marketplace
Description: Dispute an action that an eCommerce platform has taken against you
Additional-disclaimer: Please note, some online marketplaces may have additional fees. Be aware that the exact requirements may vary depending on the marketplace you received the notice from.

Main-title: Challenge the registration of a new trade mark to defend your right
Description: Oppose a trade mark you’re accused of infringing before it becomes registered

Main-title: Request IP Australia remove an unused trade mark to defend your right
Description: Request IP Australia removes an unused  trade mark from the register.
Resolution-rate: Approx 1200 applications made to IP Australia per year

Main-title: Request confirmation that someone else's registered design is valid
Description: Third-party examination lets any person request IP Australia to conduct a formal examination of a registered Australian design
Additional-disclaimer: Formal action to protect design rights — like sending a letter of demand (or cease-and-desist letter) — can only be initiated after a design right is certified. A threat to start infringement or similar proceedings against another person in respect of a design will be an unjustified threat if the design has not been certified. A person who receives such a threat can start legal action against the person making the threat: see Respond to an unjustified threat | IP Australia First Response.

Main-title: Detect and discourage potential infringement in your supply chain
Description: Ensure your partners and suppliers are not unintentionally exposing you to IP risk through unlicensed or counterfeit components.

Main-title: Identify and track your competitors' patents and activity
Description: Monitor your competitors' activity to anticipate conflicts or opportunities.

Main-title: Use your trademark prominently to build recognition and protection
Description: Make strong, visible use of your IP to increase consumer recognition and legal standing.

Main-title: CONDUCT IP AUDITS TO SPOT GAPS, REDUCE RISKS AND PLAN NEXT STEPS
Description: Identify IP in your portfolio, who owns it, what it’s worth, it’s legal status, and what to do next.

Main-title: Help customers differentiate between your products and lookalikes
Description: Build brand loyalty and reduce confusion by clearly explaining what makes your product genuine.

Main-title: Explore opportunities by licensing  your IP
Description: Consider licensing your IP to others or obtaining a licence for contested IP to avoid disputes and add value.

Main-title: Plan how IP disputes will be handled via contracts
Description: Create ready-to-use contract clauses that will proactively refer IP disputes to dispute resolution processes endorsed by the World Intellectual Property Organisation (WIPO).
Resolution-rate: In 2024, WIPO AMC helped resolve 858 intellectual property (IP) disputes.
Provider: World Intellectual Property Office Arbitration and Mediation Center

Main-title: Inform online platforms that you have IP rights
Description: Register your IP with online platforms to access their enforcement tools.

Main-title: Check your idea against existing patents.
Description: Conduct a thorough search of existing patents - also known as Freedom to Operate search.
Additional-disclaimer: A freedom to operate search does not give you a legal guarantee - but it may help you avoid costly surprises later.

Main-title: CHOOSING A ‘QUALIFIED PERSON’ (QP) to conduct growing trials
Description: Deciding who will conduct growing trials for your plant breeder’s rights application.
Additional-disclaimer: Please note: You must engage a QP even if you do not need to do an Australian growing trial.

Main-title: Monitor the trade mark register and market for competitor activity
Description: Ensure the exclusivity of your trade mark by detecting potential conflicts early.

Main-title: Register your right to use your design exclusively
Description: Submit an application to IP Australia to secure exclusive rights that protect the overall appearance that results from visual features applied to a product.
Resolution-rate: Approx 8,000 designs are registered by IP Australia each year

Main-title: Apply for a patent to protect your invention from being copied
Description: Prepare and submit formal patent applications to IP Australia to secure exclusive rights for your invention.
Resolution-rate: Over 30,000 patents are filed annually in Australia.

Main-title: DEVELOP A STRATEGY TO MANAGE YOUR IP
Description: Develop a  forward-looking intellectual property (IP) strategy that may help you take proactive steps to secure, manage and enforce your IP.
Resolution-rate: Common when multiple IP assets are held

Main-title: Check your design against existing designs
Description: Conduct a thorough search of existing registered designs - also known as Freedom to Operate search.

Main-title: Choose to rebrand to avoid potential IP conflicts
Description: Strategically rebrand your business to avoid disputes.

Main-title: Stop infringing goods entering the country
Description: Lodge a notice of objection with the Australian Border Force.
Resolution-rate: More than 500 trade mark notices are currently in force
Additional-disclaimer: Please Note: A Notice of Objection cannot act retrospectively  for goods/copies that have already been imported.

Main-title: Access help tailored to resolve business disputes
Description: Australia Small Business & Family Enterprise Ombudsman (ASBFEO)
Resolution-rate: Up to 80% of cases resolved with ASBFEO's help
Provider: Australian Small Business and Family Enterprise Ombudsman

Main-title: Dispute a domain name that infringes your trade mark
Description: Dispute a .au domain name that may infringe an IP right
Estimate-cost: $2,000+ per domain, plus optional legal fees
Resolution-rate: 40-50% of cases end in licence transfer

Main-title: Seek binding, authoritative decisions
Description: Escalate a wide range of trade mark matters to court
Resolution-rate: Court decisions are binding although appeal is possible
Additional-disclaimer: It is prudent to seek legal advice before deciding whether to start a court action. You will likely also need assistance from an IP lawyer should you decide to start a court action.   The timeframe is typically shorter if the matter is resolved through negotiations or a court-ordered mediation process.

Main-title: Resolve IP issues with the help of a third party
Description: Invite the other party to enter into mediation to agree to mutually acceptable agreement
Estimate-cost: $3k-$5k per day, plus optional legal fees

Main-title: Demand the other party stops infringing in writing
Description: Send a letter to infringing party notifying them of potential infringement
Resolution-rate: 40% of patent holders find it effective to stop copying
Additional-disclaimer: Before sending a letter of demand, you will need to be satisfied that the other party’s actions amount to infringement and it is recommended that you speak to an IP lawyer or an IP attorney. There can be serious consequences if you send a letter of demand with no basis including a risk that the party you sent the letter of demand to may sue you. IP laws include ‘unjustified threat’ provisions (also referred to as ‘groundless threats’ in copyright law) under which you might be liable to pay damages/compensation or you may be ordered to stop making the threat. For more information about what constitutes an infringement, see our information on what infringement can look like. An IP professional can help you make this assessment and draft the letter. Please note that sending a letter of demand before consulting with an IP professional may result in detrimental outcomes for you and your IP right. Please consider carefully if you want to undertake this action and are fully aware of the risks involved.  A letter of demand will also usually be more effective if it is sent by an IP lawyer or IP attorney on your behalf, rather than you sending it personally. However, you may want to consider the cost of obtaining this legal assistance against the monetary value of any compensation or licence fee you are seeking.

Main-title: Choose not to act immediately
Description: Strategically enforce your IP only when worthwhile

Main-title: Obtain legal advice on your enforcement options
Description: Seek a qualified & experienced professional to provide specific, tailored advice.

Main-title: Coverage against potential future costs related to infringement
Description: Protect yourself from some costs involved in IP disputes

Main-title: resolve conflicts with the help of experienced facilitators
Description: Understand more about the options in the ADR space.

Main-title: Remove a trade mark from the register
Description: Request IP Australia removes an unused  trade mark from the register.
Resolution-rate: Approx 1200 applications made to IP Australia per year
Additional-disclaimer: The application for removal/cessation of protection for non-use must be filed in an approved form

Main-title: Challenge the registration of a new trade mark
Description: Initiate a trade mark opposition process against a new trade mark with IP Australia

Main-title: Challenge a new or amended patent
Description: Initiate a challenge to the validity of a new patent with IP Australia

Main-title: Seek binding, authoritative decisions
Description: Escalate a wide range of patent matters to court
Resolution-rate: Court decisions are binding although appeal is possible
Additional-disclaimer: It is prudent to seek legal advice before deciding whether to start a legal action in court. You will likely also need assistance from an IP lawyer if you decide to start a legal action.

Main-title: Challenge a granted patent
Description: Request a re-examination with IP Australia, to revoke or amend a granted patent
Resolution-rate: <1% of patents are subject to re-examination

Overtitle: Sorry, This information isn't available yet
Main-title: Other IP Types
Description: We cannot provide information on this right just yet

Main-title: Remove a trade mark from the register
Description: Let IP Australia know a recently registered trade mark should not have been registered
Resolution-rate: Revocation of registration is very rare

Main-title: Access international arbitration and mediation services
Description: Seek dispute resolution through the WIPO Arbitration and Mediation Center
Resolution-rate: 92% of users prefer this over litigation to resolve cross-border disputes

Main-title: Challenge the use of international domain name
Description: Dispute an international domain name that infringes your trade mark
Estimate-cost: US$1,500+ per domain, plus optional legal fees
Additional-disclaimer: Please Note: If the infringing domain name ends in ‘.au’ then the relevant policy is the .au Dispute Resolution Policy (auDRP) provided by auDA.

Main-title: Agree to a formal commercial arrangement
Description: Work with an IP professional to come to an agreement with another party
Resolution-rate: Over 90% of commercial disputes settle outside court or arbitration

Main-title: Resolve IP issues with the help of a third party
Description: Agree to be bound by the decision of a highly qualified third-party assessment

Main-title: Seek a court order to prevent further damage while preparing for court.
Description: Lodge an interim injunction order through court
Resolution-rate: Matter will be resolved in court at later date

Main-title: Provide an opportunity for the other party to stop infringing.
Description: Alert the alleged infringer of your registered rights to allow them to stop infringing
Additional-disclaimer: There can be serious consequences if you threaten a person with infringement proceedings on an incorrect basis, including a risk that the party may sue you. You might be liable to pay compensation or damages or you may be ordered to stop making the threat under ‘unjustified threat’ provisions (also referred to as ‘groundless threats’ in copyright law).

Main-title: Considerations before enforcing your IP overseas
Description: Find the right assistance to enforce your IP right in the case of infringement happening outside of Australia.
Additional-disclaimer: Without careful attention to the local operating environment, you may risk undermining your IP right.

Main-title: Notify online marketplaces of infringement on their platform
Description: Request infringing material is removed from online marketplaces and platforms

Main-title: Register your unregistered trade mark
Description: Strengthen your position as the registered owner of your trade mark in Australia
Resolution-rate: Approximately 75% of trade mark applications achieve registration

Main-title: Ask your suppliers and sellers to help protect your IP
Description: Contact businesses you work with to raise concerns about suspected IP infringement and ask for their help preventing further infringement.

Overtitle: Report IP crime or safety concerns
Main-title: Prevent risks to public interest
Description: Inform Government about risks to public health, crime, counterfeiting, frauds & scams.
Additional-disclaimer: Sales of counterfeit goods can be reported to Crime Stoppers . If you suspect links to serious or organised crime like the above, phone 131 444 and report the matter to your local police.

Main-title: Prevent a patent under examination from being granted
Description: Submit a third-party notification of prior art (S27) to alert IP Australia to earlier work that may show a patent application lacks novelty or inventiveness and thus cannot be granted.
Resolution-rate: S27 notices are rarely submitted to IP Australia.

Main-title: Choosing the right IP professional
Description: Different professionals offer different expertise. Find out who does what, how they can help, and what to consider when choosing someone for your situation.

Main-title: Seek binding, authoritative decisions
Description: Escalate a wide range of PBR matters to court.
Resolution-rate: Court decisions are binding although appeal is possible
Additional-disclaimer: PBR court cases are rare. This means there is limited legal precedent for judges and lawyers to draw on. This makes it harder to build a strong case, increases potential costs, and adds uncertainty to how a judge might rule.

Main-title: Seek binding, authoritative decisions
Description: Escalate a wide range of design rights matters to court.
Resolution-rate: Court decisions are binding although appeal is possible
Additional-disclaimer: Designs court cases are rare. This means there is limited legal precedent for judges and lawyers to draw on. This makes it harder to build a strong case, increases potential costs, and adds uncertainty to how a judge might rule.

How to avoid infringing others' intellectual property
Description: Running a business or developing new products or services often means creating intellectual property (IP) or encountering IP rights owned by others. Whether it is a brand name, invention, design, or creative work, using something similar to someone else’s existing intellectual property may be considered infringement.

Main-title: Design infringement
Description: Design infringement can occur when someone uses a design that is identical or similar to a registered design without obtaining permission from the owner. In Australia, a registered design provides designers protection for up to 10 years. Importantly, the law does not require exact copying. If the overall visual impression of the suspected infringing design is substantially similar to the registered design, it may be considered infringemen

Main-title: Patent infringement
Description: Patent infringement can occur when someone uses an invention protected by another person’s patent without obtaining permission first. In Australia, granted patents give inventors the ability to control the use of their invention for up to 20 years (or up to 25 years for pharmaceutical patents).

Main-title: Plant breeder's rights (PBR) infringement
Description: Infringement of Plant Breeders’ Rights (PBRs) can occur when someone uses a protected variety without the owner’s permission. In Australia, PBRs last for up to 20 years or 25 years, depending on the plant type.

Main-title: Copyright infringement
Description: Copyright infringement can occur when someone uses a copyright-protected work without obtaining permission. However, the Copyright Act does provide exceptions that enable some use of copyright material without the permission of the copyright owner in certain circumstances. Importantly, infringement can occur even if only part of a copyright-protected item is used.

Main-title: Unregistered trade marks
Description: Not all trade marks used in Australian marketplaces are registered with IP Australia. In certain circumstances, the law protects these “unregistered” trade marks. The law will offer protection or remedy when someone wrongfully appropriates a brand name, logo, slogan, or another identifying mark that is too similar to someone else’s that has built up a reputation in the Australian marketplace. The use of a similar trade mark must lead to consumers being deceived or confused, and likely cause damage to the owner.

Main-title: What to do if someone infringes your IP
Description: Discovering that someone might be using your intellectual property without permission can be both frustrating and concerning. Whether it is your brand name, invention, design, or creative work, knowing how to respond appropriately is vital for protecting your rights while avoiding unnecessary costs and complications.

Main-title: Trade mark infringement
Description: Trade mark infringement can occur when someone uses a brand name, logo, slogan, or another identifying mark that is too similar to someone else’s registered trade mark,1 particularly if it is for the same or similar goods or services.2 This can lead to confusion among consumers about the source of the goods or services being offered.

Main-title: Addressing Overseas Infringement
Description: Australian businesses that discover their intellectual property (IP) is being infringed overseas face unique challenges. By understanding these challenges, they can make informed decisions about how to protect their IP internationally.

Main-title: What is IP Infringement
Description: Intellectual property infringement occurs when someone uses, reproduces, or exploits another person’s or business’s creative work, invention, brand name, or design without permission. This concept applies across all types of intellectual property (IP) rights protected under Australian law, including patents, trade marks, designs, copyright, and plant breeders’ rights.

Main-title: The Toyota story: What can SMEs learn from Toyota’s approach to counterfeit products?
Description: What can businesses do to protect themselves against importation of counterfeits that might jeopardise their brand and their products? The story of Toyota provides insight into their use of the ABF notice of objection scheme
